elements.content: A family of copper­(I)-iodide/organic hybrid compounds was investigated for the impact of coordinating organic ligands on their structures, as well as on their optical and photocatalytic properties. This included the synthesis of two new crystalline compounds, [(CuI)2(bpmd)] and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (bpmd = 2,2′-bipyrimidine, bpp = 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl)­pyrazine), both of which consist of chain structures formed by (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers that are further coordinated to the N-groups of the bridging organic ligands. To more broadly investigate structure–property relationships within this system, nine related copper­(I)-iodide/organic hybrid compounds, that is, [(CuI)2L n ] (n = 1 or 2; L = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl) ethylene (bpe); 2,2′-bipyrimidine (bpmd); 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl) pyrazine (bpp); 4,4′-bipyridine (44bpy); pyridazine (pdz); pyrimidine (pmd); pyrazine (pz); pyrazinamide (pza); quinoxaline (quin)) were also prepared in high purity containing extended (CuI)∞ chains or sheets coordinated to bridging or terminating organic ligands. The optical absorption edges of all hybrid compounds were measured using UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. Incorporation of the organic ligand functions to significantly decrease the bandgap size with respect to the parent γ-CuI (E g = 3.1 eV = optical band gap) into the visible-light wavelengths spanning from ∼1.7 to ∼2.6 eV for the [(CuI)2L n ] family. Their optical bandgap sizes were found to be controlled specifically by the framework density, the number of N atoms bonded to each Cu atom, and the number of N atoms in each heterocyclic ring within the ligands. Their photocatalytic properties were investigated and found to show high activity for the light-driven degradation of methylene blue, for example, degrading as fast as within ∼20 min for [(CuI)­(pza)]. These photocatalytic activities were found to be related to the orbital energies of the Cu 3d10 and I 5p6 relative to that of the organic ligands, as well as to the local and extended connectivity of their crystalline structures. In contrast to the instability of other metal halide compounds, for example, lead-based halide perovskites, all copper­(I)-iodide hybrids were found to be stable within aqueous solutions while under irradiation by ultraviolet and visible light. These results demonstrate the stability and photocatalytic activity copper­(I)-iodide/organic hybrids in light-driven redox reactions.

elements.content: Copper-iodide/organic hybrid compounds with low-dimensional structures were synthesized and investigated. Their bandgap sizes were found to be related to their framework densities and interactions between the copper cations and the organic ligands and which exhibit high photocatalytic activities for organic dye degradation.
elements.clean_text: Copper-iodide/organic hybrid compounds with low-dimensional structures were synthesized and investigated. Their bandgap sizes were found to be related to their framework densities and interactions between the copper cations and the organic ligands and which exhibit high photocatalytic activities for organic dye degradation.

elements.content: The coordination chemistry of Cu­(I) is quite varied but commonly exhibiting tetrahedral coordination due to the lack of crystal field stabilization energy. The relatively small highest occupied molecular orbital–lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO–LUMO) gap allows a wide range of coordination compounds observed for Cu­(I), with the high-lying and filled 3d-orbitals and the low-lying and empty 4s- and 4p-orbitals allowing reactivity to electrophiles and nucleophiles, respectively. The coordination flexibility allows the formation of a wide variety of Cu­(I) complexes with various physical and chemical properties, such as luminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The coordination chemistry of Cu(I) is quite varied but commonly exhibiting tetrahedral coordination due to the lack of crystal field stabilization energy. The relatively small highest occupied molecular orbital-lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO-LUMO) gap allows a wide range of coordination compounds observed for Cu(I), with the high-lying and filled 3d-orbitals and the low-lying and empty 4s- and 4p-orbitals allowing reactivity to electrophiles and nucleophiles, respectively. The coordination flexibility allows the formation of a wide variety of Cu(I) complexes with various physical and chemical properties, such as luminescence.

elements.content: One family of Cu­(I) complexes, Cu­(I)-halide/organic hybrids, are constructed from Cu­(I) halide units with organic ligands occupying one or more of the four coordination sites on Cu­(I), having the general formula of Cu x X y L z (where X = Cl, Br, or I; L = organic ligand). Cu­(I)-halide/organic hybrids can form as discrete compounds, such as the Cu4I4py4 cluster in which pyridine ligands are coordinated to the four Cu­(I) sites in the Cu4I4 cubane. The Cu4I4py4 clusters exhibit luminescence, which has been attributed to metal-to-ligand and halide-to-ligand charge transfer. Cu­(I)-halide/organic hybrids can also exist as CuX based building blocks (“connectors”) linked by organic ligands in coordination polymers. Coordination polymers, with metal–organic frameworks as a subclass, are a class of materials containing extended structures constructed from metal cation centers linked by organic ligands. With the coordination flexibility and luminescent properties of Cu­(I) complexes, coordination polymers constructed with Cu­(I) halide aggregates possess significant structural diversity and unique physical properties, thereby enabling crystal engineering in both their local coordination chemistry as well as extended structure connectivity. With different bridging organic ligands, various Cu­(I) halide architectures, such as rhombus dimer connectors, zigzag chains, and staircase chains, have been constructed, which extend the crystal engineering of Cu­(I) halides from discrete oligomers to coordination polymers with one, two, and three-dimensional structures. In addition, a number of attractive physical and chemical properties have been found in Cu­(I) halide/organic hybrids, such as luminescence and light-driven surface reactivity.

Cu(I)-halide/organic hybrids can form as discrete compounds, such as the Cu4I4py4 cluster in which pyridine ligands are coordinated to the four Cu(I) sites in the Cu4I4 cubane. The Cu4I4py4 clusters exhibit luminescence, which has been attributed to metal-to-ligand and halide-to-ligand charge transfer. Cu(I)-halide/organic hybrids can also exist as CuX based building blocks ("connectors") linked by organic ligands in coordination polymers. Coordination polymers, with metal-organic frameworks as a subclass, are a class of materials containing extended structures constructed from metal cation centers linked by organic ligands. With the coordination flexibility and luminescent properties of Cu(I) complexes, coordination polymers constructed with Cu(I) halide aggregates possess significant structural diversity and unique physical properties, thereby enabling crystal engineering in both their local coordination chemistry as well as extended structure connectivity. With different bridging organic ligands, various Cu(I) halide architectures, such as rhombus dimer connectors, zigzag chains, and staircase chains, have been constructed, which extend the crystal engineering of Cu(I) halides from discrete oligomers to coordination polymers with one, two, and three-dimensional structures. In addition, a number of attractive physical and chemical properties have been found in Cu(I) halide/organic hybrids, such as luminescence and light-driven surface reactivity.

elements.content: By comparison, copper iodide, sans organic ligands, has itself been investigated over the last five to six decades with increasing interest. It has been applied to a variety of fields, such as catalysts, light-emitting diodes, and solar cells. Copper iodide forms in the zinc-blende structure below 643 K (γ-CuI), wurtzite structure between 643 and 673 K (β-CuI), and rock-salt structure above 673 K (α-CuI). The zinc-blende structure consists of two interpenetrating face-centered-cubic (fcc) lattices displaced along a body diagonal with both cations and anions in tetrahedral coordination geometries. This compound is a direct band gap semiconductor with a bandgap size of 3.1 eV and the valence band originating primarily from the filled 3d10 orbitals of the Cu­(I) cations and the 5s and 5p orbitals of the iodide anions. As compared to condensed γ-CuI, Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids containing tetrahedrally coordinated Cu­(I) cations have been found to exhibit reduced bandgap sizes, that is, into the visible-light region of the solar spectrum, owing to the incorporation of (unoccupied) ligand orbitals within the band gap. In contrast to the well-known halide perovskites, for example, CH3NH3PbI3, which have been used to construct highly efficient solar cells but are unstable in air, relatively little has been reported concerning their stability and photocatalytic activities in aqueous solutions for water purification or fuel-producing redox reactions. Presented herein, the relationships between the crystalline structures, optical bandgap sizes, and stable photocatalytic activities of a large family Cu­(I)–iodide/hybrids are investigated as a function of the coordinating organic ligands.

elements.content: The organic ligands 4,4′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl) ethylene, and 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl) pyrazine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and all other organic reagents were purchased from Alfa Aesar. All organic reagents were used as received without further purification. CuI was purchased from Alfa Aesar and purified by recrystallization from concentrated aqueous KI solution. The purity of purified CuI was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), which also confirmed that the purified CuI exists as the γ-phase at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Materials

The organic ligands 4,4'-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl) ethylene, and 2,3-bis(2-pyridyl) pyrazine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and all other organic reagents were purchased from Alfa Aesar. All organic reagents were used as received without further purification. CuI was purchased from Alfa Aesar and purified by recrystallization from concentrated aqueous KI solution. The purity of purified CuI was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), which also confirmed that the purified CuI exists as the γ-phase at room temperature.

elements.content: [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1). CuI (0.1904 g; 1 mmol) was dissolved in ∼20 mL of acetonitrile. A sample of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) of 2,2′-bipyrimidine was added to the solution such that the CuI/ligand molar ratio in the starting materials matched the stoichiometry of the final product. An orange-brown precipitate formed immediately. After stirring the mixture at ∼70 °C for 3 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with acetone, and then dried in air at room temperature. Single crystals of 1 were obtained by a three-layer crystallization: the bottom layer was 1 mmol CuI dissolved in 3 mL of saturated aqueous KI solution; the middle layer was 3 mL of pure acetonitrile; and the top layer was a solution of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) 2,2′-bipyrimidine dissolved in 3 mL of acetone. Crystals appeared after 3–4 days and were isolated under an optical microscope.

[(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1). CuI (0.1904 g; 1 mmol) was dissolved in ~20 mL of acetonitrile. A sample of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) of 2,2'-bipyrimidine was added to the solution such that the CuI/ligand molar ratio in the starting materials matched the stoichiometry of the final product. An orange-brown precipitate formed immediately. After stirring the mixture at ~70 °C for 3 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with acetone, and then dried in air at room temperature. Single crystals of 1 were obtained by a three-layer crystallization: the bottom layer was 1 mmol CuI dissolved in 3 mL of saturated aqueous KI solution; the middle layer was 3 mL of pure acetonitrile; and the top layer was a solution of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) 2,2'-bipyrimidine dissolved in 3 mL of acetone. Crystals appeared after 3-4 days and were isolated under an optical microscope.

elements.content: [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2). CuI (0.1904 g; 1 mmol) was dissolved in ∼20 mL of acetonitrile. A sample of 0.5 mmol (0.1171 g) of 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl) pyrazine was added to the solution such that the CuI/ligand molar ratio in the starting materials matched the stoichiometry of the final product. A dark brown precipitate formed immediately. After stirring the mixture at ∼70 °C for 3 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with acetone, and then dried in air at room temperature. Single cyrstals of 2 were obtained under similar conditions as described for 1. All other Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids were synthesized under similar conditions as described for 1.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected at room temperature using a Rigaku R-axis Spider Powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation from a sealed tube X-ray source (40 kV, 36 mA). PXRD patterns were scanned with a step size of 0.02° over the 2θ angular range from 5° to 75° and dwell times of 4 s for each step. Single crystal data for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] and [(CuI)2(bpp)] were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a sealed tube source. A representative brown plate-like crystal of [(CuI)2(bpmd)], approximate dimensions 0.084 mm × 0.124 mm × 0.139 mm, and a representative dark green rodlike crystal of [(CuI)2(bpp)], approximate dimensions 0.071 mm × 0.081 mm × 0.185 mm, were selected for X-ray crystallographic analyses. The frames were integrated within the Bruker SAINT software package using a narrow-frame algorithm. The structures were solved and refined using the SHELX software package. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and were fixed to ride on the parent carbon atoms. Selected crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] and [(CuI)2(bpp)] are listed in .

Structural Characterization

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected at room temperature using a Rigaku R-axis Spider Powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54056 Å) radiation from a sealed tube X-ray source (40 kV, 36 mA). PXRD patterns were scanned with a step size of 0.02° over the 2θ angular range from 5° to 75° and dwell times of 4 s for each step. Single crystal data for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] and [(CuI)2(bpp)] were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a sealed tube source. A representative brown plate-like crystal of [(CuI)2(bpmd)], approximate dimensions 0.084 mm × 0.124 mm × 0.139 mm, and a representative dark green rodlike crystal of [(CuI)2(bpp)], approximate dimensions 0.071 mm × 0.081 mm × 0.185 mm, were selected for X-ray crystallographic analyses. The frames were integrated within the Bruker SAINT software package using a narrow-frame algorithm. The structures were solved and refined using the SHELX software package. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and were fixed to ride on the parent carbon atoms. Selected crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] and [(CuI)2(bpp)] are listed in .

Midinfrared (400–4000 cm–1) spectra were measured on an IR-Prestige 21 Shimadzu Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer (FTIR) equipped with a GladiATR accessory. Approximately 5 mg of powder was loaded onto the sample stage, and the data were plotted as transmittance versus wavenumber. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV-3600/3100 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. A pressed barium sulfate powder tablet was used as the reference. The data were plotted as the remission function F(R ∞) = (1 – R ∞)2/(2R ∞) versus energy, where R ∞ is diffuse reflectance according to the Kubelka–Monk theory of diffuse reflectance. The optical bandgap sizes were estimated with the formula E g (eV) = 1240/λg (nm), where λg is extrapolated from the linear rising part in the spectra. Thermogravimetric analyses were taken on a TA Instruments TGA Q50 by loading 1.5–3 mg of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] or [(CuI)2(bpp)] onto a platinum pan. The pan was equilibrated and tared at room temperature and heated to 800 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min under flowing N2. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was carried out by spreading each of the powdered materials onto double-sided carbon tape (SPI supplies) and introducing to an ultrahigh vacuum chamber (base pressure less than 10–10 Torr). A nonmonochromatic Mg Ka X-ray source was used along with a MAC 2 photoelectron spectrometer. Binding energies were calibrated by assigning the C 1s core level to be at 284.5 eV. For this study, XPS analysis was carried out on five representative compounds: (CuI)2(44bpy), (CuI)2(pyridine), (CuI)2(pz), (CuI)­(44bpy), and (CuI)2(pyrimidine).

elements.content: To measure the photocatalytic properties of all 11 compounds and γ-CuI, ∼30 mg of powder of each was added to a 35 mL of solution of 1 × 10–5 M of methylene blue (MB). The suspension was magnetically stirred in the dark for ∼20 min to ensure adsorption equilibrium and uniform dispersity. The mixture was then exposed to visible light irradiation from a 1000 W mercury lamp with a visible light lens to ensure only visible light reaches the mixture, while being magnetically stirred at room temperature. Every 10 min approximately 4 mL of the mixture was withdrawn and left on the lab bench for precipitation of the solid. Absorbance of the clear liquid was then measured using a Shimadzu UV-3600/3100 UV–vis-NIR spectrophotometer to monitor the change in concentration of MB during the dye degradation process. After 60 min, the reaction mixture was removed from the irradiation of visible light, and the solid was recovered by centrifugation. PXRD patterns were taken on each recovered solid sample and compared to the PXRD patterns of the as-prepared solid samples to test for any structural changes during the dye degradation process.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Organic Dye Degradation

To measure the photocatalytic properties of all 11 compounds and γ-CuI, ~30 mg of powder of each was added to a 35 mL of solution of 1 × 10-5 M of methylene blue (MB). The suspension was magnetically stirred in the dark for ~20 min to ensure adsorption equilibrium and uniform dispersity. The mixture was then exposed to visible light irradiation from a 1000 W mercury lamp with a visible light lens to ensure only visible light reaches the mixture, while being magnetically stirred at room temperature. Every 10 min approximately 4 mL of the mixture was withdrawn and left on the lab bench for precipitation of the solid. Absorbance of the clear liquid was then measured using a Shimadzu UV-3600/3100 UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer to monitor the change in concentration of MB during the dye degradation process. After 60 min, the reaction mixture was removed from the irradiation of visible light, and the solid was recovered by centrifugation. PXRD patterns were taken on each recovered solid sample and compared to the PXRD patterns of the as-prepared solid samples to test for any structural changes during the dye degradation process.

elements.content: The structures of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) are shown in . Structure 1 is constructed from rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 motifs bridged by the bpmd ligands to give one-dimensional chains with each Cu bonded to two N atoms at 2.093 Å. The chains of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] units align down the b-axis direction. Adjacent chains are stacked in a staggered manner so that the (CuI)2 rhomboids in alternate chains are related by half a translation with respect to each other. A short CuCu distance is formed (∼2.529 Å) across the rhombus diagonal.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions

The structures of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) are shown in . Structure 1 is constructed from rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 motifs bridged by the bpmd ligands to give one-dimensional chains with each Cu bonded to two N atoms at 2.093 Å. The chains of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] units align down the b-axis direction. Adjacent chains are stacked in a staggered manner so that the (CuI)2 rhomboids in alternate chains are related by half a translation with respect to each other. A short CuCu distance is formed (~2.529 Å) across the rhombus diagonal.

elements.content: Structure of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) down the c-axis and structure of [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) down the b-axis. Blue spheres are Cu, purple spheres are I, brown spheres are carbon, light blue spheres are nitrogen, and light pink spheres are hydrogen.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) down the c-axis and structure of [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) down the b-axis. Blue spheres are Cu, purple spheres are I, brown spheres are carbon, light blue spheres are nitrogen, and light pink spheres are hydrogen.

elements.content: Similarly, 2 is also constructed from (CuI)2 motifs bridged by the ligands to give one-dimensional chains. Shown in , the (CuI)2 motifs form in a bent rhombus shape with one pyridine ring of bpp rotated above the pyrazine plane while the other is rotated below the plane such that each Cu is bonded to two N atoms at 2.073 Å. The chains of [(CuI)2(bpp)] units align down the b-axis direction. Adjacent chains pack in a staggered manner so that (CuI)2 distorted rhomboids in alternate chains are related by half a translation with respect to each other. A short CuCu distance is found (2.557 Å) across the distorted rhombus diagonal. The similar structures of 1 and 2 arise from the similar geometries of their bridging organic ligands and which connect in a linear fashion for 1 but are offset for 2.

elements.content: Other synthesized Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids have diverse structures. [(CuI)2(pdz)2] is similarly composed of one-dimensional chains constructed by (CuI)2 rhombus dimers bridged by pdz ligands on both sides of the rhomboid plane, shown in . However, in [(CuI)­(pza)] the (CuI)2 rhomboids are replaced by staircase-shaped (CuI)∞ chains wherein each Cu­(I) cation is also bonded to a single pza ligand, . The higher-dimensional (CuI)∞ connectivity arises from the singly coordinating and terminating pza ligand versus the chelating ligands in the prior structures that yield (CuI)2 rhombii. By contrast, the structure of [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] shown in , contains the singly coordinating and bridging 44bpy ligand, and there are again (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers that are interconnected to form interpenetrating honeycomb sheets. [(CuI)2(pdz)] forms a sheet-type of structure, which is constructed from (CuI)4 tetramers with a twisted-chain conformation bridged by pdz ligands, shown in . The [(CuI)2(pz)], [(CuI)2(pmd)], [(CuI)2(quin)], [(CuI)2(44bpy)], and [(CuI)2(bpe)] are all isomorphous and composed of a sheet-type of structure, which is constructed by an extended (CuI)∞ staircase chain linked by the coordinating organic ligands and packed in a zigzag fashion, .

elements.content: The IR spectra of all Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids are given in the Supporting Information, Figure S1, and are consistent with the functional groups of their corresponding organic ligands. The spectra of the coordination polymers are all mostly the same as their corresponding ligands except that a few peaks, such as the peak for CC vibration in the aromatic ring, exhibit slight blue shifts (∼10 cm–1) compared to their corresponding ligands.

The spectra of the coordination polymers are all mostly the same as their corresponding ligands except that a few peaks, such as the peak for CC vibration in the aromatic ring, exhibit slight blue shifts (~10 cm-1) compared to their corresponding ligands.

elements.content: Across this Cu­(I)–iodide/organic family of structures, the connectivity of the inorganic (CuI) n component, that is, whether connected into isolated rhombus-shaped dimers, chains, or sheets, is determined by the coordination mode and geometry of the organic ligand. Chelating and/or bridging organic ligands that occupy two of the coordinating sites of the Cu­(I) cations lead to rhombus-shaped dimers in 1, 2, and [(CuI)2(pdz)2], as examples. However, terminating ligands that occupy only a single coordination site on the Cu­(I)-centered tetrahedral coordination environments lead to structures with more extended −I–Cu–I–Cu– connectivity, such as the (CuI)∞ chains in [(CuI)­(pza)] or in [(CuI)2(pdz)] containing a two-dimensional connectivity of the (CuI)∞ inorganic component. A change in the amount of ligand, that is, from a Cu/L molar ratio of 1:1 to 2:1, can result in a higher-dimensional −I–Cu–I–Cu– connectivity as found in the structures of [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] and [(CuI)2(44bpy)], that respectively contain (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped units or (CuI)∞ staircase chains. Thus, the number and type of occupation (i.e., bridging or terminal) of the tetrahedral Cu­(I) sites can be used to control the framework dimensionality within these low-dimensional structures.

Chelating and/or bridging organic ligands that occupy two of the coordinating sites of the Cu(I) cations lead to rhombus-shaped dimers in 1, 2, and [(CuI)2(pdz)2], as examples. However, terminating ligands that occupy only a single coordination site on the Cu(I)-centered tetrahedral coordination environments lead to structures with more extended -I-Cu-I-Cu- connectivity, such as the (CuI)∞ chains in [(CuI)(pza)] or in [(CuI)2(pdz)] containing a two-dimensional connectivity of the (CuI)∞ inorganic component. A change in the amount of ligand, that is, from a Cu/L molar ratio of 1:1 to 2:1, can result in a higher-dimensional -I-Cu-I-Cu- connectivity as found in the structures of [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] and [(CuI)2(44bpy)], that respectively contain (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped units or (CuI)∞ staircase chains. Thus, the number and type of occupation (i.e., bridging or terminal) of the tetrahedral Cu(I) sites can be used to control the framework dimensionality within these low-dimensional structures.

elements.content: Thermal analyses data for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) are plotted in . The weight loss curves indicate that 1 is stable in air up to ∼284 °C, whereas 2 is stable up to ∼259 °C. The thermogravimetric curve for 1 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 284–380 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl., 28.59%; calcd., 29.34%). In the range of ∼380–572 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. The curve for 2 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 259–357 °C was similarly owing to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl, 35.74%; calcd, 38.04%). Over the temperature range of ∼355–667 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. Thus, these compounds show significantly higher stability in air than the corresponding Pb-containing iodide perovskites. XPS spectra after several weeks in air also show unchanged oxidation states and coordination environments of the Cu­(I) cations, given in the Supporting Information in Figure S4.

Thermal Stability

Thermal analyses data for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) are plotted in . The weight loss curves indicate that 1 is stable in air up to ~284 °C, whereas 2 is stable up to ~259 °C. The thermogravimetric curve for 1 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 284-380 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl., 28.59%; calcd., 29.34%). In the range of ~380-572 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. The curve for 2 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 259-357 °C was similarly owing to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl, 35.74%; calcd, 38.04%). Over the temperature range of ~355-667 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. Thus, these compounds show significantly higher stability in air than the corresponding Pb-containing iodide perovskites. XPS spectra after several weeks in air also show unchanged oxidation states and coordination environments of the Cu(I) cations, given in the Supporting Information in Figure S4.

elements.content: XPS spectra near the Cu 2p core levels are shown in Figure S4 (Supporting Information) for five representative compounds. These spectra show the fingerprint line shape for the Cu­(I) oxidation state. This is indicated by the lack of a prominent shakeup satellite on the high binding energy side of the main Cu 2p3/2 peak that would indicate the presence of the Cu­(II) oxidation state. On the basis of these measurements, we conclude that the compounds considered here are very air stable because they were stored in ambient air for more than one month prior to the XPS measurements. Under similar conditions, many copper­(I)-oxide compounds typically show evidence of Cu­(II) oxides or hydroxides at least near the surface. By contrast, the compounds considered by XPS show no serious ambient reactivity of the Cu­(I) cations. Other core-level spectra of the I 3d and N 1s (Figure S4) also show no evidence of significant ambient reactivity.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy

XPS spectra near the Cu 2p core levels are shown in Figure S4 (Supporting Information) for five representative compounds. These spectra show the fingerprint line shape for the Cu(I) oxidation state. This is indicated by the lack of a prominent shakeup satellite on the high binding energy side of the main Cu 2p3/2 peak that would indicate the presence of the Cu(II) oxidation state. On the basis of these measurements, we conclude that the compounds considered here are very air stable because they were stored in ambient air for more than one month prior to the XPS measurements. Under similar conditions, many copper(I)-oxide compounds typically show evidence of Cu(II) oxides or hydroxides at least near the surface. By contrast, the compounds considered by XPS show no serious ambient reactivity of the Cu(I) cations. Other core-level spectra of the I 3d and N 1s (Figure S4) also show no evidence of significant ambient reactivity.

elements.content: Control over bandgap size is a critical parameter in tuning materials for the absorption and utilization of solar energy within many chemical systems, including metal oxides, chalcogenides, and other systems. However, relatively little is known regarding the relationships of optical bandgap sizes of metal halides to their structures and chemical compositions. Optical diffuse reflectance spectra of the Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids were measured, and the results are plotted in and listed in . Interestingly, all compounds exhibit distinct bandgap edges with their absorption extending to increasing energies, even for those structures containing rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 dimers. This likely results from the relatively high covalent interactions to the coordinating organic ligands that link the (CuI) n dimers, chains, or sheets units together. Each of the hybrid compounds also exhibits significantly reduced bandgap sizes compared to pure γ-CuI (i.e., E g = 3.1 eV) within a range that spans deep into the visible-light energies from ∼1.71 to ∼2.60 eV. However, there appears to be an unexpected trend of the bandgap sizes with the dimensionality of the −I–Cu–I–Cu– connectivity. For example, [(CuI)2(44bpy)] with (CuI)∞ chains exhibits a bandgap size of ∼2.44 eV, whereas [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] containing rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 dimers shows a smaller bandgap size of ∼2.13 eV. This trend is opposite to that expected, which is that lower dimensionalities yield larger bandgap sizes. Similarly, [(CuI)2(pdz)] containing (CuI)∞ sheets and [(CuI)2(pdz)2] with (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers have band gaps of ∼2.31 and ∼2.18 eV, respectively. Thus, these trends clearly show that the optical bandgap sizes are not a simple function of the dimensionality of the inorganic (CuI) n components.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Bandgap Sizes

Control over bandgap size is a critical parameter in tuning materials for the absorption and utilization of solar energy within many chemical systems, including metal oxides, chalcogenides, and other systems. However, relatively little is known regarding the relationships of optical bandgap sizes of metal halides to their structures and chemical compositions. Optical diffuse reflectance spectra of the Cu(I)-iodide/organic hybrids were measured, and the results are plotted in  and listed in . Interestingly, all compounds exhibit distinct bandgap edges with their absorption extending to increasing energies, even for those structures containing rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 dimers. This likely results from the relatively high covalent interactions to the coordinating organic ligands that link the (CuI) n  dimers, chains, or sheets units together. Each of the hybrid compounds also exhibits significantly reduced bandgap sizes compared to pure γ-CuI (i.e., E g = 3.1 eV) within a range that spans deep into the visible-light energies from ~1.71 to ~2.60 eV. However, there appears to be an unexpected trend of the bandgap sizes with the dimensionality of the -I-Cu-I-Cu- connectivity. For example, [(CuI)2(44bpy)] with (CuI)∞ chains exhibits a bandgap size of ~2.44 eV, whereas [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] containing rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 dimers shows a smaller bandgap size of ~2.13 eV. This trend is opposite to that expected, which is that lower dimensionalities yield larger bandgap sizes. Similarly, [(CuI)2(pdz)] containing (CuI)∞ sheets and [(CuI)2(pdz)2] with (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers have band gaps of ~2.31 and ~2.18 eV, respectively. Thus, these trends clearly show that the optical bandgap sizes are not a simple function of the dimensionality of the inorganic (CuI) n  components.

elements.content: In this equation, V is the volume of the unit cell and Z is the number of formula units in each unit cell, and thus Z/V is the framework density, which suggests that the bandgap size decreases as the framework density increases, consistent with prior observations. Additionally, the bandgap size is inversely related to the ratio of the number of nitrogen atoms bonded to each copper atom to the average number of nitrogen atoms per heterocyclic ring in the organic ligands. For example, in [(CuI)2(bpp)], each Cu­(I) cation is bonded to two nitrogen atoms. With a total of four nitrogen atoms and three aromatic rings in each bpp ligand, the average number of N per ring is 4/3. Shown in b, the bandgap size is inversely proportional to the scaled framework density.

elements.content: The bandgap size for γ- CuI is ∼3.1 eV, which is represented in b as the black cross on the y-axis. The relationship between the bandgap sizes of all hybrid compounds and the scaled framework densities was fitted with a linear function, shown as the dashed line in b. Interestingly, the y-intercept of the linear function is close to the bandgap size of pure γ-phase CuI. With the zinc-blend structure of γ-phase CuI, each Cu­(I) cation is tetrahedrally coordinated by four iodide anions. The HOMO of CuI consists of the 3d10 orbitals of Cu­(I) mixed with the 5p6 orbitals of iodide and which interact and constitute the valence band. The conduction band of CuI derives from the antibonding orbital interactions of CuI. It has been suggested that the LUMO of some types of organic ligands, that is, the π* orbitals, are located within the CuI band gap. Thus, the bandgap sizes of the Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids are also dependent upon the empty ligand π* orbitals with lower energy LUMO states on the ligand contributing to a decreased bandgap size. An increased number of N atoms in the heterocyclic rings of a ligand leads to higher energy LUMO states due to the energy mismatch between N and C atoms. A decreased number of heterocyclic rings in a ligand molecule leads to less conjugation and thus destabilizing the ligand molecule, which also results in higher energy LUMO states. Thus, an increased number of N atoms in the ligand and/or a decreased number of heterocyclic rings, that is, an increased average number of N atoms per heterocyclic ring, lead to an increased LUMO energy and thus a larger bandgap size. For example, across the compounds containing the (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers there is a fairly consistent bandgap size of ∼2.13–2.18 eV independent of the organic ligand. The exception is [(CuI)2(bpp)] with a smaller bandgap size of ∼1.71 eV, likely owing to the bpp (i.e., 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl)­pyrazine)) ligand-based π* orbitals falling within the band gap. Conversely, an increased number of ligand-based nitrogen atoms bonded to the Cu­(I) cations and displacing the iodide anions from its coordination environment, causes decreased Cu–I interactions and smaller bandgap sizes. Thus, the higher-dimensional I–Cu–I–Cu connectivities of [(CuI)2(44bpy)] and [(CuI)2(pdz)] lead to larger bandgap sizes than the lower-dimensional structures of the related [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] and [(CuI)2(pdz)2]. Thus, within this structural family, the dimensionality of the I–Cu–I–Cu connectivity has the opposite effect of what is the typically observed trend with bandgap size.

A decreased number of heterocyclic rings in a ligand molecule leads to less conjugation and thus destabilizing the ligand molecule, which also results in higher energy LUMO states. Thus, an increased number of N atoms in the ligand and/or a decreased number of heterocyclic rings, that is, an increased average number of N atoms per heterocyclic ring, lead to an increased LUMO energy and thus a larger bandgap size. For example, across the compounds containing the (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers there is a fairly consistent bandgap size of ~2.13-2.18 eV independent of the organic ligand. The exception is [(CuI)2(bpp)] with a smaller bandgap size of ~1.71 eV, likely owing to the bpp (i.e., 2,3-bis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine)) ligand-based π* orbitals falling within the band gap. Conversely, an increased number of ligand-based nitrogen atoms bonded to the Cu(I) cations and displacing the iodide anions from its coordination environment, causes decreased Cu-I interactions and smaller bandgap sizes. Thus, the higher-dimensional I-Cu-I-Cu connectivities of [(CuI)2(44bpy)] and [(CuI)2(pdz)] lead to larger bandgap sizes than the lower-dimensional structures of the related [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] and [(CuI)2(pdz)2]. Thus, within this structural family, the dimensionality of the I-Cu-I-Cu connectivity has the opposite effect of what is the typically observed trend with bandgap size.

elements.content: The photocatalytic activities of each of the 11 Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids were investigated for the degradation of an organic dye, that is, methylene blue (MB), and which has potential applications for water purification technologies. Their activities were tested to determine the impact of the structure and bandgap sizes upon their ability to facilitate light-driven redox reactions at the surfaces. During the photocatalytic degradation of MB in water, the compounds absorb photons with energies greater than their bandgap sizes, which leads to electron transfer from the valence band to the conduction band, creating positive holes in the valence band. The holes can then directly oxidize the carboxylic acid groups in MB and resulting in its degradation. Each sample was suspended in an aqueous solution of the MB dye and irradiated under only visible light, and the concentration of MB was measured and plotted versus time.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Activities

The photocatalytic activities of each of the 11 Cu(I)-iodide/organic hybrids were investigated for the degradation of an organic dye, that is, methylene blue (MB), and which has potential applications for water purification technologies. Their activities were tested to determine the impact of the structure and bandgap sizes upon their ability to facilitate light-driven redox reactions at the surfaces. During the photocatalytic degradation of MB in water, the compounds absorb photons with energies greater than their bandgap sizes, which leads to electron transfer from the valence band to the conduction band, creating positive holes in the valence band. The holes can then directly oxidize the carboxylic acid groups in MB and resulting in its degradation. Each sample was suspended in an aqueous solution of the MB dye and irradiated under only visible light, and the concentration of MB was measured and plotted versus time.

elements.content: As shown in , a wide range of photocatalytic rates was observed. The lowest photocatalytic degradation rate was found for [(CuI)2(bpp)] which has the smallest bandgap size of ∼1.71 eV and contains the (CuI)2 dimers but with an almost zero degradation of MB measured after 60 min. Among the structures consisting of the rhombus-shaped (CuI)2 dimers, the photocatalytic rate increased with larger bandgap sizes, that is , in the order of [(CuI)2(bpp)] < [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] < [(CuI)2(bpmd)] < [(CuI)2(pdz)2]. The highest rates for MB degradation corresponded to two hybrids containing (CuL)∞ chains, that is, [(CuI)­(pza)] and [(CuI)2(bpe)], illustrating the importance of extended −I–Cu–I–Cu– structural connectivity in order for the photon-generated carriers to reach their surfaces. For [(CuI)­(pza)], nearly all of the MB was degraded after being irradiated in visible light for ∼20 min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of each of the hybrids showed no measurable changes after recovery from the MB degradation experiments, as shown in Figure S2 in the Supporting Information, indicating no change in structures or compositions during these light-driven reactions, which demonstrated their catalytic properties as well as their stability in aqueous solution. One exception was [(CuI)2(pdz)2], which showed slight changes in its PXRD pattern after MB degradation likely because of a slight decomposition of [(CuI)2(pdz)2] toward the end of the degradation experiment from the increase in the temperature of the solution. By comparison, γ-CuI shows only minimal photocatalytic activity for the degradation of MB, and thus illustrating the impact of the coordinating ligands on photocatalytic reactions.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed in order to understand how the differences in structures and organic ligands impact the electronic structures of the Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids and thus their photocatalytic properties. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was utilized as encoded in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof for the exchange-correlation functionals. The plane wave cut-off was set at 520 eV, and a 6 × 6 × 6 k-point mesh was used for the densities-of-states calculations (DOS). Shown in are the DOS plots of [(CuI)­(pza)] with the highest photocatalytic activity, [(CuI)2(bpp)] with the lowest photocatalytic activity, and [(CuI)2(quin)] with an intermediate photocatalytic activity. Results of the DOS plots for the other hybrid compounds are given in Figure S3 in the Supporting Information. As shown in and S3, the LUMOs of the ligands, represented by the N, C, and H orbitals (also O orbitals for [(CuI)­(pza)]) with low DOS, are at energies higher than the filled Cu 3d orbitals of Cu and filled 5s and 5p orbitals of I. This is consistent with previous observations that LUMOs of the ligands are located within the band gap of CuI. In [(CuI)2(bpp)], the filled orbitals of Cu and I are both much lower in energy than the LUMOs of the ligand, and even much lower than the filled bonding orbitals of the ligands. The lowest-energy transition occurs on the bpp ligand orbitals alone, that is, between its HOMO/LUMO energy states. The conduction and valence band edges of [(CuI)2(bpp)] contain very little contributions from the Cu-based and/or I-based orbitals, which must be critical in the photocatalytic degradation of MB. For the other hybrid compounds, filled Cu 3d orbitals and 5s and 5p orbitals of iodine are higher in energy and just below the LUMOs of the ligands. This indicates that copper-to-ligand and iodine-to-ligand transitions likely dominate at the band edges, yielding a larger bandgap size and sufficient electrochemical potential to oxidize MB, such as found for [(CuI)2(44bpy)2] and [(CuI)2(bpmd)] that also contain the (CuI)2 dimers.

elements.content: As shown in , [(CuI)­(pza)] is the only hybrid compound with a chain structure with each organic ligand bonded to a single Cu­(I) cation, that is, it is the only compound in which the (CuI)∞ network is not bridged through the organic ligands. It also shows the highest photocatalysis rates for the degradation of MB. During a metal-to-ligand bandgap transition, electrons are transferred from one (CuI)∞ chain to the pza ligand. However, the pza ligand is not bridged to any other (CuI)∞ chains, and this potentially helps to inhibit the recombination of the excited electron with a hole on a neighboring chain. Other hybrid compounds contain coordinating ligands that bridge two (CuI) n components. In order for the photocatalytic degradation of MB to occur, the holes in the valence band must have sufficient electrochemical potential but not recombine quickly with the excited electrons in the conduction band. Therefore, these results show that their photocatalytic activities are closely related to the LUMOs of the organic ligands, whether the bandgap excitation involves transitions between more delocalized orbitals on (CuI) n (i.e., higher activities for extended chains versus dimers) or between HOMO/LUMO levels of the ligand orbitals alone.

It also shows the highest photocatalysis rates for the degradation of MB. During a metal-to-ligand bandgap transition, electrons are transferred from one (CuI)∞ chain to the pza ligand. However, the pza ligand is not bridged to any other (CuI)∞ chains, and this potentially helps to inhibit the recombination of the excited electron with a hole on a neighboring chain. Other hybrid compounds contain coordinating ligands that bridge two (CuI) n  components. In order for the photocatalytic degradation of MB to occur, the holes in the valence band must have sufficient electrochemical potential but not recombine quickly with the excited electrons in the conduction band. Therefore, these results show that their photocatalytic activities are closely related to the LUMOs of the organic ligands, whether the bandgap excitation involves transitions between more delocalized orbitals on (CuI) n  (i.e., higher activities for extended chains versus dimers) or between HOMO/LUMO levels of the ligand orbitals alone.

elements.content: A family of low-dimensional copper­(I)-iodide/organic hybrids was synthesized that contain (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers, or (CuI)∞ chains or sheets, bridged by coordinating organic ligands. The dimensionality of the −I–Cu–I–Cu– network is found to be primarily determined by the number of bonds the organic ligands form to the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu­(I) cations. All of the hybrid compounds show significantly reduced bandgap sizes of ∼1.7–2.6 eV, compared to pure γ-CuI of ∼3.1 eV. Their optical bandgap sizes were found to be inversely proportional to the framework density and the number of nitrogen atoms bonded to copper­(I) cations. Both are related to the strength of the interactions between Cu­(I) atoms and organic ligands, and proportional to the number of nitrogen atoms in the N-heterocyclic rings of the ligands. Their visible-light photocatalytic activities for degradation of the MB vary significantly with the higher rates generally measured for the compounds with extended (CuI)∞ chains. The electrochemical potential generated by the bandgap excitation from the filled copper and iodide orbitals to the ligand-based π* orbitals, as well as the slow recombination of the holes in the valence band and the excited electrons in the conduction band, are both critical to higher photocatalytic activities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A family of low-dimensional copper(I)-iodide/organic hybrids was synthesized that contain (CuI)2 rhombus-shaped dimers, or (CuI)∞ chains or sheets, bridged by coordinating organic ligands. The dimensionality of the -I-Cu-I-Cu- network is found to be primarily determined by the number of bonds the organic ligands form to the tetrahedrally coordinated Cu(I) cations. All of the hybrid compounds show significantly reduced bandgap sizes of ~1.7-2.6 eV, compared to pure γ-CuI of ~3.1 eV. Their optical bandgap sizes were found to be inversely proportional to the framework density and the number of nitrogen atoms bonded to copper(I) cations. Both are related to the strength of the interactions between Cu(I) atoms and organic ligands, and proportional to the number of nitrogen atoms in the N-heterocyclic rings of the ligands. Their visible-light photocatalytic activities for degradation of the MB vary significantly with the higher rates generally measured for the compounds with extended (CuI)∞ chains. The electrochemical potential generated by the bandgap excitation from the filled copper and iodide orbitals to the ligand-based π* orbitals, as well as the slow recombination of the holes in the valence band and the excited electrons in the conduction band, are both critical to higher photocatalytic activities.

cln_elements.content:
[(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1). CuI (0.1904 g; 1 mmol) was dissolved in ∼20 mL of acetonitrile. A sample of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) of 2,2′-bipyrimidine was added to the solution such that the CuI/ligand molar ratio in the starting materials matched the stoichiometry of the final product. An orange-brown precipitate formed immediately. After stirring the mixture at ∼70 °C for 3 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with acetone, and then dried in air at room temperature. Single crystals of 1 were obtained by a three-layer crystallization: the bottom layer was 1 mmol CuI dissolved in 3 mL of saturated aqueous KI solution; the middle layer was 3 mL of pure acetonitrile; and the top layer was a solution of 0.5 mmol (0.0791 g) 2,2′-bipyrimidine dissolved in 3 mL of acetone. Crystals appeared after 3–4 days and were isolated under an optical microscope.

[(CuI)2(bpp)] (2). CuI (0.1904 g; 1 mmol) was dissolved in ∼20 mL of acetonitrile. A sample of 0.5 mmol (0.1171 g) of 2,3-bis­(2-pyridyl) pyrazine was added to the solution such that the CuI/ligand molar ratio in the starting materials matched the stoichiometry of the final product. A dark brown precipitate formed immediately. After stirring the mixture at ∼70 °C for 3 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with acetone, and then dried in air at room temperature. Single cyrstals of 2 were obtained under similar conditions as described for 1. All other Cu­(I)–iodide/organic hybrids were synthesized under similar conditions as described for 1.

cln_elements.content: Thermal analyses data for [(CuI)2(bpmd)] (1) and [(CuI)2(bpp)] (2) are plotted in . The weight loss curves indicate that 1 is stable in air up to ∼284 °C, whereas 2 is stable up to ∼259 °C. The thermogravimetric curve for 1 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 284–380 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl., 28.59%; calcd., 29.34%). In the range of ∼380–572 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. The curve for 2 showed that the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 259–357 °C was similarly owing to the decomposition of the bpmd ligand (weight loss: exptl, 35.74%; calcd, 38.04%). Over the temperature range of ∼355–667 °C, the weight loss corresponds to the sublimation of iodine and CuI. Thus, these compounds show significantly higher stability in air than the corresponding Pb-containing iodide perovskites. XPS spectra after several weeks in air also show unchanged oxidation states and coordination environments of the Cu­(I) cations, given in the Supporting Information in Figure S4.

b. Goodness of fit = (Σ­[w(F<sub>o</sub><sup>2</sup> – F<sub>c</sub><sup>2</sup>)<sup>2</sup>]/(number of reflns – number of parms))<sup>1/2</sup>
